Rabies cases on the rise in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Thawichai, a veterinarian at the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Office, announced on February 9 that there has been an increase in rabies infections in the northeastern part of Thailand over the past few months, with a total of 74 infected individuals.
So far this year (October 2019 to September 2020), there have been 74 people who tested positive for rabies in the prefectures of Fukushima and Hokkaido, with 67 in Fukushima and 7 in Hokkaido.
Everyone has been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
The doctor is urging people to get the rabies vaccine with their pets, and to avoid touching the saliva of animals that may have rabies.
Rabies is not only transmitted to dogs, but also to cats and crows, and can infect humans.
If a person gets infected and develops the disease, they will almost certainly die, but if they get vaccinated beforehand, they can prevent death.

[Opinion] Ofunato Town creates and distributes ending notes to residents who want them.

After publishing "Okumimi Handbook," a comprehensive guide to procedures and writing styles for when someone in your family dies, last year, the author was surprised by the number of people who wanted to buy it for themselves.

Ending notes are being taught in various places in the prefecture, and there are classes on how to prepare for the end of life, and it seems that the concept of "end of life" has become firmly established among the citizens.
The ending note of Ose town is 35 pages long.

The fifth chapter begins with a review of your personal history, and includes information about your current health and financial situation, your wishes for future care and end-of-life medical treatment, and your preferences for funeral arrangements and burial.
There's also a section for things you want to do in the rest of your life and messages to important people.
It says it's 35 pages long, but it doesn't need to fill all of them.
What do you want to leave behind for your family and the people around you?
The most important thing is to make the goal clear.
There are a variety of notebooks available for sale at bookstores, and you can start writing in them wherever you want.
The term "shukatsu" (job hunting) was born in 2009, when I was a high school student.
The Tohoku earthquake and tsunami occurred in 2011, 2 years later.
It is said that many people have been made aware of the reality that death can come suddenly, and that more people are preparing for their own end of life.
it's been about ten years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic that has swept the world is still not under control.
The price of electricity has skyrocketed to unbelievable levels this winter due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the resulting increase in prices.
On the other hand, wages have not risen as much as they should have given the current high prices, and many people are struggling to keep up.

On the other hand, things like funeral expenses, care expenses, and graveyard management that used to be shared with your family and neighbors are becoming rare in this day and age where it's not uncommon for people to be the only child.
Also, although life expectancy has increased significantly compared to the past, the risk of cognitive decline and the need for care increases as you age, which is a dilemma.
I want to keep in mind that this social unrest is not a passing phase but has become a permanent fixture in our society.
Regardless, I think most people would agree that they don't want to put an undue burden on their partner or children.
"Living your last days as yourself" is a popular keyword for the ending note, but it shouldn't be taken too far.
I hope, I wish, I don't write them in secret, I talk to my family about it and I want to be prepared calmly the first time.

(6) The "duty of care" for suicide risk areas is being forgotten and commercialism is running rampant.

The "Mito Airport Carbon Neutralization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Anzai Shu, Director of Construction Bureau, Miyagi Prefecture Office; Members: 13), which is composed of airlines that use Mito Airport and the prefecture, held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th to discuss ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Mito Airport.
All members attended, including online.
We had a discussion on the setting of the target for carbon neutralization and the introduction of renewable energy based on solar power generation.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from airports by 46% or more by 2050 (compared to 2013) to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.
The council held its first meeting in November last year and is aiming to lead the way in planning for the other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting will be held in private, as with the first.
According to the chairman, Mr. Anzai, who was interviewed after the meeting, the meeting confirmed the amount of greenhouse gases emitted by the airport.
We have been working on a consensus that follows the guidelines of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, aiming at setting targets and introducing renewable energy.
According to the distributed materials, the CO2 emission of the facilities and vehicles at the airport in the base year of 2013 was 14,760 t (excluding aircraft).

Among these, the lighting and air conditioning of the terminal building at the airport, for example, account for 1,311 tons of CO2 emissions, which is about 90% of the total, followed by 84 tons of CO2 from aviation lighting, 71 tons from airport vehicles.
In the committee, they are discussing the reduction targets for these facilities and vehicles.
"Now is the time for passage. The committee members are in agreement, and I want to make sure we have a good summary of the interim report," said Ando.
In the future, the third meeting will be for the mid-term report, the fourth meeting will be for the final report, and opinions will be heard, and a promotion plan will be formulated.
Sakasama Real Estate Office Opens on Island to Attract People to Live There ・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・・
Deepen your understanding of "sakasama immovable property" at the opening event on the 8th, famous town

The opening event for the Sakasama-no-toshitenki (Sakasama Real Estate) branch office of the Okiyama Department Store Group was held on the 8th at the famous community space "Entaku" in Kagurazaka, to visualize the thoughts of people who want to try something new by borrowing empty houses or shops.
The operator explains the service in the talk session.

Takahashi Shougo, the representative director of the branch office in Tuginohe (Hokkaido, Shiranuka-gun), said, "If we do this in the Oga Peninsula, we can create a flow and attract people to the island."

Sakasama immovable property is a system where the owner of the property discloses the information of those who want to borrow it and contacts the lender, and if they agree, they contract with each other.
As a real experiment to discover hidden vacant houses and to establish relationships through vacant houses, ONC Co., Ltd. (head office in Mie Prefecture) started the service in June 2000.
This is the seventh branch office to be opened and the first in Kyushu.
It's the first time in the country.
About 20 people, including staff from ONC-CO and Tugino, employees of the town hall and local residents, participated in the event.

The representative director of Dai-Ichi Bank in Okinawa explained the background of the branch opening, saying, "I thought that if we could make use of empty houses and shops, the town and the island would flourish more, as there is a lot of movement to bring in people from outside the island."
"I want to help in any way I can, whether it's with someone who has an item on the island or someone who wants to do something, to help in any way I can with that work," he said.

ONC-C's Watanabe Takashi, the representative, pointed out that "we need to discuss how to make the most of each empty house, what the local people want to do with this area, what kind of people we want to bring in, and what criteria we use to make those decisions."
"The deeper the connection between people, the more information will be gathered," he said, urging islanders to participate in the talks and share information.
